Dialogue.Student: Hi! I’m Sophia Wang. This is my first time here.
Dialogue.Counselor: Hello, Sophia! It’s great to meet you. How can I assist you today?
Dialogue.Student: I’m feeling a bit frustrated with my graphic design class.
Dialogue.Counselor: I’m sorry to hear that. What’s been particularly frustrating for you?
Dialogue.Student: We have a group project on mental health awareness, and one of my teammates, Liam, seems really disengaged.
Dialogue.Counselor: That sounds challenging. Have you had a chance to reach out to Liam about how you’re feeling?

Dialogue.Student: Hi again. Things have gotten a bit more complicated.
Dialogue.Counselor: Welcome back, Sophia! What’s been going on?
Dialogue.Student: I tried to take the lead by presenting my ideas in the last meeting, but everyone seemed indifferent and unresponsive, especially Liam.
Dialogue.Counselor: That must be discouraging. How did that make you feel?
Dialogue.Student: It made me anxious about my ability to lead the group. I doubt my capacity to motivate my teammates.
Dialogue.Counselor: Those feelings are completely valid. Leadership can be tough, especially when you want to inspire others. Have you considered how you might try to engage your team again?

Dialogue.Student: Hi. I’m feeling very burnt out right now.
Dialogue.Counselor: Hi Sophia. I’m here to help. What’s contributing to your burnout?
Dialogue.Student: With the project deadline nearing, I’ve taken on most of the work, hoping to compensate for Liam and others. My presentation rehearsal went poorly, and I felt embarrassed afterward.
Dialogue.Counselor: It sounds incredibly overwhelming, especially when you’ve put in so much effort. Have you reached out to anyone in your group for help or support?
Dialogue.Student: No, I don't want to add to their stress. I feel so isolated right now.
I finally opened up to my family about the group project, and they encouraged me to talk to my teammates.
Dialogue.Counselor: I’m glad to hear that, Sophia! How did it feel sharing your struggles with your family?
Dialogue.Student: It felt relieving, but I’m still unsure about how to approach my team. I want to communicate honestly but without causing more tension.
Dialogue.Counselor: That’s a thoughtful approach. Remember, open communication can help foster understanding. What do you think you’ll say to them?
Dialogue.Student: I want to express my feelings but I’m not sure how to frame it.
Dialogue.Counselor: Perhaps you could write down your thoughts. It might help organize what you want to communicate. You can do this, I believe in you!
